General course objectives:
General course objectives
This course provides the theoretical pre-requisites, the background and the basis for the design of new structures and the assessment of existing structures in our built environment. Through the course, students will acquire knowledge, skills and expertise on probabilistic modelling, assessment and updating in the fields of natural hazards, structural information, structural reliability and risks and ultimately for engineering decisions including the Value of Information.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Implement decision analyses
Evaluate engineering decisions before and after implementation
Select, determine, verify and update probabilistic models in the fields of natural hazards, structural information, structural reliability and risks and engineering decisions
Select proper analyses tools for structural reliability, structural risk and decision analyses
Select appropriate distributions of random variables for stationary random processes
Determine limit state functions with basic probabilistic concepts and definitions
Perform structural reliability analyses using the First Order Reliability Method (safety index) and Monte Carlo simulation
Create and evaluate probabilistic models for structural information
Summarize data with numerical and graphical data analysis
Explain the definition and concept of random variables, vectors and processes
Explain the fundamental concepts of reliability and risk based design and assessment of structures
Content: Elements of probability theory; Random variables and vectors; Graphical and numerical data analysis; Probabilistic modelling including parameter estimation; Model verification and updating; Stochastic processes; Applications in civil engineering; Introduction to structural reliability theory; Bayesian theory; Engineering decision analysis
Course literature: Faber, M.H. (2012) Statistics and Probability theory: In Pursuit of Engineering Decision Support, Springer.
